Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Enzyme design for economical feed additives from sugar
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) project is to develop low-cost, high-performing feed additives for the swine feed market. Some of the current additives that supplement feed have detrimental side effects and/or made from raw materials that are considered toxic. Additives made from these toxic raw materials need to undergo substantial purification to meet the safety thresholds. This project will develop new enzymes and processes that enable the synthesis of chemically and structurally identical additives from renewable feedstocks. The combination of enzyme design and process optimization will result in an environmentally-friendly process to produce additives that require minimal purification and result in low production costs. The goal is to develop novel enzymes that are suited to produce feed additives that have a proven record of safety and efficacy.

This STTR Phase I project is a proposal to address the availability of renewably-sourced feed additives by developing a new enzyme and a process. Currently, many feed additives are produced using organic chemical synthesis that require energy intensive unit operations. The required extensive clean-up of these products, combined with the high containment cost, translates into high operating expenses. This project will focus on developing new catalytic capabilities for enzymes by improving their selectivity and specificity. Using the newly engineered enzymes in a process that involves efficient unit operations, it will be possible for the first time to produce low-cost feed additives that have a proven history of performance and safe use. By employing powerful enzyme design tools to create enzyme libraries through gene synthesis, this project will screen for promising enzyme candidates that have desired capabilities. The deliverable of the Phase I project will be a conclusive demonstration of the technical, economic and market feasibility of the concept.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Sasya is a technology development enterprise, delivering pragmatic, sustainable solutions for producing performance-driven supplements. Sasya has embarked on a bold journey to design and engineer enzymes to alter their functionality such that they can be effectively used to produce proven dietary supplements. With investment from the NSF, Sasya is developing the technology for the production of Syretin?, a potent dietary supplement that is proven to increase lean and muscle.

Increased urbanization is rapidly leading to increased awareness for healthier lifestyle and environmental health. Market reports project an optimistic forecasting for the growth of dietary supplements for humans, pets and animals. Paradoxically, many of supplements are produced using energetically expensive chemical synthesis with a low yield and/or toxic byproduct production and therefore, harm the environment. Sasya is developing a new fermentation-based process to produce targeted high-performance supplements with large markets. The research reported here involved enzyme design and process optimization to result in an environmentally-responsible process to produce supplements that require minimal purification. These favorable attributes translate into lower production costs and larger margins.

In this project, Sasya employed new tools in computational enzyme engineering and genomics to successfully lay the foundation for developing Syretin?. The fortuitous confluence of the availability of enabling technology and market conditions facilitated completion of the project, which would not have been possible even five years ago. As a dietary supplement, Syretin? is widely used by athletes for enhancing their performance and by post-surgery and immune-compromised patients to prevent sarcopenia. In the Phase I of the project, Sasya has significantly de-risked enzyme development and subsequent fermentation to produce Syretin?. As a proof-of-concept, Sasya produced sample quantities of Syretin? (see image) and is poised to embark on a larger technology development and optimization mission to take the project to commercial fruition.

Modified by: Goutham N Vemuri
